Establishing Criteria for the Permanent Protection of Prime Farmland and Strategies for Intergrating Agricultural Production Infrastructure
YUN HYUNGCHANG
Department of Rural and Biosystems Engineering
Graduate School of Chonnam National University
(Supervised by Professor YOO Seung-Hwan)
(Abstract)

Korea's agricultural land area has drastically decreased over the past half-century, declining approximately 00% from 0000 million hectares in 1970 to 0000 million hectares in 2022, with the food self-sufficiency rate standing at only 00%. Under these circumstances, with accelerating climate change and rural aging, the foundation of national food security is being threatened. The current agricultural promotion area system shows structural limitations as it relies on simple area-based criteria established on the agricultural structure of the 1970s (10ha for plains, 7ha for intermediate areas, 3ha for mountainous areas), failing to consider the spatial configuration structure and functional connectivity of farmland.

This study aimed to establish a scientific and objective prime farmland evaluation system using landscape ecological approaches and spatial analysis techniques in Haenam County, Jeollanam-do, and to propose permanent farmland protection policy measures linked with agricultural production infrastructure. Using FRAGSTAT software, landscape indices representing farmland fragmentation, aggregation, and morphological efficiency were calculated, and production potential analysis using detailed soil maps and accessibility evaluation of agricultural production infrastructure through Cost-Distance analysis were conducted. Subsequently, an integrated evaluation model was developed by applying Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and Multi-Criteria Evaluation (MCE) techniques.

The analysis results showed that Haenam County's farmland generally exhibited high aggregation (AI average 00.0) and cohesion (COHESION average 0.00), but significant variation in fragmentation levels was observed across regions. The western plain areas centered on reclaimed land showed high structural efficiency, while urban periphery and eastern hilly areas exhibited serious fragmentation problems. Through comparative analysis with current agricultural promotion areas, it was confirmed that even with the same area, actual agricultural value differs significantly according to spatial configuration structure.

This study proposed new agricultural promotion area designation criteria that comprehensively consider farmland structural efficiency, functional value, and infrastructure connectivity, and developed an investment priority decision model for agricultural production infrastructure. These research results are expected to contribute to a paradigm shift in farmland conservation policy from simple area-based 'quantitative conservation' to 'qualitative management' based on scientific evidence.
Keywords: Prime farmland, Agricultural promotion areas, FRAGSTAT, Landscape ecology, Agricultural production infrastructure, Multi-criteria evaluation
